https://technews.tw/2020/03/02/three-sou:
3 月 2 日公布的統計數據顯示，近年電動車的接受度越來越高，南韓電動車電池主要供應商的市場版圖持續擴大，合計全球市占在 1 月創下新高。韓聯社報導，南韓前三大 EV 電池製造商為樂金化學（LG Chem）、三星能源材料（Samsung SDI）和 SK Innovation。根據南韓研調機構 SNE Research 發表的最新研究報告，以全球純電動車（EV）車載電池使用量估算，三者合計全球市占率於 1 月達到 30.8%，創下歷來最佳表現。觀察個別業者表現，樂金化學排名全球第 2，市占率達 22.9%，較去年同期的 9% 增加 1 倍以上。SNE Research 分析，樂金化學在 EV 電池市場市占率攀升，主要來自雷諾（Renault）電動車 ZOE 和奧迪（Audi）純電車 e-tron 銷售良好，帶動樂金化學的擴張速度。三星 SDI 1 月市占率為 5.1%，排名全球第 4，SK Innovation 則以 2.8% 名列第 7，排名較去年上升 5 位。SNE Research 指出，BMW 插電式油電混合車 330e 和福斯（Volkswagen）Passat GTE，是三星 SDI 市占率增長的最主要關鍵因素，而 SK Innovation 則受惠於起亞汽車（Kia Motors）的電動車 Niro 和 Soul Booster 銷售所帶動。由於特斯拉（Tesla）Model 3 在全球大受歡迎，日本松下（Panasonic）1 月以 27.6% 的市占率，高居 EV 電池市場榜首，中國鋰電池龍頭寧德時代（CATL）則拿下 21.9% 市占率，位居全球第 3。《BusinessKorea》2 月 27 日報導，隨著歐盟制定更嚴格的汽車廢氣排放法規，電動車在歐洲市場銷量快速成長。今年 1 月，德國、法國、英國、義大利和瑞典共售出 44,361 輛電動車，較去年同期大幅成長 149%，其中德國銷量大增 138.4%，達到 16,131 輛，法國、英國、義大利和瑞典的銷量也分別增長 160.1%、145.5%、490.5% 及 93.4%。全球電動車電池需求也同步上升。2019 年，全球電動車電池需求/供應量分別為 190 GWh / 326 GWh，預估 2021 年將分別增至 599 GWh / 458 GWh，並在 2023 年達到 776 GWh / 916 GWh。報導指出，樂金化學 EV 電池業務，今年營收可望超過 10 兆韓圜，較去年的 8.3 兆韓圜進一步增加。三星 SDI 看好 EV 電池業務今年營收年增 7 成，SK Innovation 目標則是 EV 電池業務今年營收達到 2 兆韓圜。（本文由 MoneyDJ新聞 授權轉載；首圖來源：shutterstock）科技新知，時時更新我的最愛趕快加入最愛頁面Facebook成為我們的小粉絲GOOGLE加入我們一起討論RSS即時更新新知

https://simplywall.st/news/how-many-sams:
If you want to know who really controls Samsung SDI Co., Ltd. (KRX:006400), then you’ll have to look at the makeup of its share registry. Insiders often own a large chunk of younger, smaller, companies while huge companies tend to have institutions as shareholders. Companies that have been privatized tend to have low insider ownership.  Samsung SDI is a pretty big company. It has a market capitalization of ₩19t. Normally institutions would own a significant portion of a company this size. Our analysis of the ownership of the company, below, shows that institutions are noticeable on the share registry. Let’s delve deeper into each type of owner, to discover more about Samsung SDI.  Check out our latest analysis for Samsung SDI  Many institutions measure their performance against an index that approximates the local market. So they usually pay more attention to companies that are included in major indices.  As you can see, institutional investors own 42% of Samsung SDI. This suggests some credibility amongst professional investors. But we can’t rely on that fact alone, since institutions make bad investments sometimes, just like everyone does. When multiple institutions own a stock, there’s always a risk that they are in a ‘crowded trade’. When such a trade goes wrong, multiple parties may compete to sell stock fast. This risk is higher in a company without a history of growth. You can see Samsung SDI’s historic earnings and revenue, below, but keep in mind there’s always more to the story.  We note that hedge funds don’t have a meaningful investment in Samsung SDI. Our data shows that Samsung Electronics Co., Ltd. is the largest shareholder with 21% of shares outstanding. Next, we have National Pension Service and BlackRock, Inc. as the second and third largest shareholders, holding 11% and 3.5%, of the shares outstanding, respectively.  Additionally, we found that the top 13 have the combined ownership of 50% in the company, suggesting that no one share holder has significant control over the company.  While studying institutional ownership for a company can add value to your research, it is also a good practice to research analyst recommendations to get a deeper understand of a stock’s expected performance. There are plenty of analysts covering the stock, so it might be worth seeing what they are forecasting, too.  The definition of an insider can differ slightly between different countries, but members of the board of directors always count. Management ultimately answers to the board. However, it is not uncommon for managers to be executive board members, especially if they are a founder or the CEO.  Most consider insider ownership a positive because it can indicate the board is well aligned with other shareholders. However, on some occasions too much power is concentrated within this group.  Our most recent data indicates that insiders own less than 1% of Samsung SDI Co., Ltd.. Being so large, we would not expect insiders to own a large proportion of the stock. Collectively, they own ₩2.5b of stock. In this sort of situation, it can be more interesting to  see if those insiders have been buying or selling.   With a 38% ownership, the general public have some degree of sway over A006400. While this size of ownership may not be enough to sway a policy decision in their favour, they can still make a collective impact on company policies.  It appears to us that public companies own 21% of A006400. We can’t be certain, but this is quite possible this is a strategic stake. The businesses may be similar, or work together.  It’s always worth thinking about the different groups who own shares in a company. But to understand Samsung SDI better, we need to consider many other factors. To that end, you should be aware of the   1 warning sign  we’ve spotted with Samsung SDI .  Ultimately the future is most important. You can access this free report on analyst forecasts for the company. NB: Figures in this article are calculated using data from the last twelve months, which refer to the 12-month period ending on the last date of the month the financial statement is dated. This may not be consistent with full year annual report figures.If you spot an error that warrants correction, please contact the editor at editorial-team@simplywallst.com. EV battery packs made by LG Chem. (image: LG Chem Ltd.)SEOUL, March 25 (Korea Bizwire) — LG Chem Ltd., South Korea’s leading chemical company, said Wednesday it has shuttered its electric vehicle battery plant in the United States due to the novel coronavirus pandemic.Samsung SDI Co., a South Korean manufacturer of electric vehicle and smartphone batteries, also said it has closed its battery pack plant in Michigan.The two plants in the state will remain closed until April 13 after Michigan Governor Gretchen Whitmer issued a stay-at-home order across the state to stem the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.The order took effect on Tuesday in Michigan, where more than 1,300 virus cases have been confirmed.Currently, LG Chem has five battery plants in South Korea, China, the United States and Poland, with a combined capacity of 70 gigawatt-hours.The South Korean chemical giant plans to raise its capacity to 100 GWh, enough to supply batteries to 1.6 million electric vehicles, by the end of this year.LG Chem supplies electric vehicle batteries to 13 of the top 20 car brands, including German automaker Volkswagen, French carmaker Renault, American auto giant General Motors and South Korea’s largest carmaker, Hyundai Motor.(Yonhap)Your email address will not be published.
